Now, define some function of frequency DT(ω) which equals Tcn at the points ω = nω0, i.e. DT(nω0) = Tcn, n = −∞, ..., −1, 0, 1, ..., +∞ (2) 8 / 28 Introduction Mathematical Formulation DT therefore looks like: ω0 2ω0 3ω0 Frequency ω c1T c2T c3T Figure 5: The function DT(ω) (cn are shown as real-valued) 9 / 28 Introduction Mathematical Formulation • Hence we can write DT(nω0) = Tcn = ∫ T/2 −T/2 f(t)e−jω0ntdt (3) • A suitable possibility for the function DT(ω) which satisfies the constraint of (3) is simply obtained by replacing nω0 with a continuous variable ω in the above formula: DT(ω) = ∫ T/2 −T/2 f(t)e−jωtdt (4) • As we increase the period T, so ω0 decreases, and the discrete points DT(nω0) define the whole function DT(ω) for all values of ω. 10 / 28 Introduction Mathematical Formulation • The Fourier Transform F(ω) is obtained as the limit of DT(ω) as T → ∞, i.e. F(ω) = Lim T→∞D(ω) = lim T→∞ ∫ T/2 −T/2 f(t)e−jωtdt = ∫ ∞ −∞ f(t)e−jωtdt The Fourier transform is often referred to as the Fourier spectrum of a signal. Comment: why is there a factor of T in the derivation? (See (3)). This serves to ‘normalise’ the integral - otherwise the integral would be zero for most functions! 11 / 28 Introduction Mathematical Formulation Interpretation of Fourier Transform • The Fourier Transform is one of the most important and useful tools of signal analysis and mathematics in general. • The Fourier series showed how to split a periodic signal into its constituent frequency components at ω0, 2ω0, ... • Since the Fourier transform is derived as a limiting case of a Fourier series (T → ∞), we can interpret it in a similar way. With the Fourier transform, however, we can analyse non-periodic functions and obtain their frequency components at any frequency ω . • Thus the Fourier transform is a much more generally applicable tool. 12 / 28 Introduction Mathematical Formulation Example Consider the ‘double exponential’ function (with a > 0): f(t) = { −30 −20 −10 0 10 20 30 0 0.2 0.4 0.6 0.8 1 13 / 28 Introduction Mathematical Formulation Calculate the Fourier transform of f(t): F(ω) = ∫ ∞ −∞ f(t)e−jωtdt = ∫ 0 −∞ eate−jωtdt + ∫ ∞ 0 e−ate−jωtdt = The following figure shows the Fourier coeﬀicients cnT for 3 increasing values of T.
